The product of two natural numbers is greater than 1 if and only if
at least one of them is greater than 1 and both are positive.

name: Nat.one_lt_mul_iff
docString:
The product of two natural numbers is greater than 1 if and only if
at least one of them is greater than 1 and both are positive.

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples.

name: Nat.dvd_right_iff_eq
docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples.

The sum of two natural numbers is even if and only if both numbers are even or both are odd.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m + n) ↔ (Even m ↔ Even n)
name: Nat.even_add
docString: The sum of two natural numbers is even if and only if both numbers are even or both are odd.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the number `n + 1` is even if and only if `n` is not even. In other words, if `n` is an odd number, then `n + 1` is an even number, and vice versa.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m + n) = (Even m ↔ Even n)
name: Mathlib.Data.Nat.Parity._auxLemma.13
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the number `n + 1` is even if and only if `n` is not even. In other words, if `n` is an odd number, then `n + 1` is an even number, and vice versa.

If `n` is even and `a` is even, then `n % a` is even.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even n → Even a → Even (n % a)
name: Even.mod_even
docString: If `n` is even and `a` is even, then `n % a` is even.

If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m ^ n) ↔ Even m ∧ n ≠ 0
name: Nat.even_pow
docString:
If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.

Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

name: Nat.dvd_left_iff_eq
docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

A natural number is odd iff it has residue `1` or `3` mod `4`

name: Nat.odd_mod_four_iff
docString: A natural number is odd iff it has residue `1` or `3` mod `4`

Any nonzero natural number is the product of an odd part `m` and a power of
two `2 ^ k`.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, n ≠ 0 → ∃ k m, Odd m ∧ n = 2 ^ k * m
name: Nat.exists_eq_two_pow_mul_odd
docString:
Any nonzero natural number is the product of an odd part `m` and a power of
two `2 ^ k`.

If `a` is even, then `n` is even iff `n % a` is even.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Even (n % a) ↔ Even n)
name: Even.mod_even_iff
docString: If `a` is even, then `n` is even iff `n % a` is even.

The set of natural numbers that are sums of two squares is closed under multiplication.

type: ∀ {a b x y u v : ℕ}, a = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 → b = u ^ 2 + v ^ 2 → ∃ r s, a * b = r ^ 2 + s ^ 2
name: Nat.sq_add_sq_mul
docString: The set of natural numbers that are sums of two squares is closed under multiplication.

A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.)

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, (∃ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) ↔ ∀ {q : ℕ}, Nat.Prime q → q % 4 = 3 → Even (padicValNat q n)
name: Nat.eq_sq_add_sq_iff
docString:
A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.)

If `a` is even, then `n` is odd iff `n % a` is odd.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Odd (n % a) ↔ Odd n)
name: Odd.mod_even_iff
docString: If `a` is even, then `n` is odd iff `n % a` is odd.

If `n` is odd and `a` is even, then `n % a` is odd.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Odd n → Even a → Odd (n % a)
name: Odd.mod_even
docString: If `n` is odd and `a` is even, then `n % a` is odd.

The convolution of two even functions is also even.

type:
∀ {�� : Type u��} {G : Type uG} {E : Type uE} {E' : Type uE'} {F : Type uF} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E'] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F] {f : G → E} {g : G → E'} {x : G}
  [inst_3 : NontriviallyNormedField ��] [inst_4 : NormedSpace �� E] [inst_5 : NormedSpace �� E'] [inst_6 : NormedSpace �� F]
  (L : E →L[��] E' →L[��] F) [inst_7 : MeasurableSpace G] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure G} [inst_8 : NormedSpace ℝ F]
  [inst_9 : AddCommGroup G] [inst_10 : μ.IsAddLeftInvariant] [inst_11 : μ.IsNegInvariant] [inst_12 : MeasurableNeg G]
  [inst_13 : MeasurableAdd G],
  (∀ᵐ (x : G) ∂μ, f (-x) = f x) →
    (∀ᵐ (x : G) ∂μ, g (-x) = g x) → MeasureTheory.convolution f g L μ (-x) = MeasureTheory.convolution f g L μ x
name: MeasureTheory.convolution_neg_of_neg_eq
docString: The convolution of two even functions is also even.

The product of two positive elements is positive.

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [self : StrictOrderedRing α] (a b : α), 0 < a → 0 < b → 0 < a * b
name: StrictOrderedRing.mul_pos
docString: The product of two positive elements is positive.

Subsequent Fibonacci numbers are coprime,
see https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Consecutive_Fibonacci_Numbers_are_Coprime

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), (Nat.fib n).Coprime (Nat.fib (n + 1))
name: Nat.fib_coprime_fib_succ
docString:
Subsequent Fibonacci numbers are coprime,
see https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Consecutive_Fibonacci_Numbers_are_Coprime

The product of two positive extended real numbers is positive.

type: ∀ {a b : EReal}, 0 < a → 0 < b → 0 < a * b
name: EReal.mul_pos
docString: The product of two positive extended real numbers is positive.

name: Nat.evenOddStrongRec

Two positive naturals are equal if their prime padic valuations are equal

type: ∀ (a b : ℕ), a ≠ 0 → b ≠ 0 → (a = b ↔ ∀ (p : ℕ), Nat.Prime p → padicValNat p a = padicValNat p b)
name: Nat.eq_iff_prime_padicValNat_eq
docString: Two positive naturals are equal if their prime padic valuations are equal

The product of two `n`-smooth numbers is an `n`-smooth number.

type: ∀ {m₁ m₂ n : ℕ}, m₁ ∈ n.smoothNumbers → m₂ ∈ n.smoothNumbers → m₁ * m₂ ∈ n.smoothNumbers
name: Nat.mul_mem_smoothNumbers
docString: The product of two `n`-smooth numbers is an `n`-smooth number.

A natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if `n = a^2 * b` with natural
numbers `a` and `b` such that `-1` is a square modulo `b`.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, (∃ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) ↔ ∃ a b, n = a ^ 2 * b ∧ IsSquare (-1)
name: Nat.eq_sq_add_sq_iff_eq_sq_mul
docString:
A natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if `n = a^2 * b` with natural
numbers `a` and `b` such that `-1` is a square modulo `b`.
